ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Spending a relatively unstructured semester doing research for my senior essay has been helpful in teaching me how to hone a bibliography, conduct ethnographic interviews, process my fieldnotes, and rethink my conceptual frameworks. Despite a lack of formal classroom instruction, I've improved my skills as an anthropological researcher this semester and look forward to continuing my project into the spring.
Landscape review of sources for my senior thesis

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I wish the ANTH department offered a bit more formalized structure for the senior essay. It would be great to have a social and academic cohort of seniors working on their essays, whether that meant weekly seminar-style check-ins, writing groups, or even just social study breaks. It definitely feels a bit isolating to work on this project alone compared to the structures in place in some larger departments.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I'd recommend this semester of research if you have a strong relationship with an ANTH faculty member and are motivated to explore your topic of study. If not, it could be difficult to carve out meaningful time for research given other classes and commitments.
